The term transclude was shamelessly stolen from AngularJS. It does the same there.

cc-transclude allows you to include clones of parts of the dom elsewhere in the document, specified by the value of the attribute and the value of the cc-transclude-base on a parent element.

You don't usually set cc-transclude-base yourself. Instead, the attribute is added by module code for, for example, cc-template and cc-include to refer to the original content, before the inclusion happened. The @transclude module then generates a transclude-sel attribute next to the cc-transclude attribute, which does the real work.

So you would only use cc-transclude inside a template or included file, to refer to the original contents of the node before the inclusion took place, and the below example is just plain weird.
  • 20 male, 20 female
  • 40 male, 23 female
  • 13 male, 4 female
  • 24 total
  • 34 total
  • 4 total
